column1: Robert Half International Inc. (RHI) on Tuesday reported fourth-quarter net income of $47 million. Earnings, adjusted for pretax expenses, were 65 cents per share. For the year, the company reported profit of $290.6 million, or $2.33 per cent. Robert Half shares hit $57.40, a rise of 24 percent in the last 12 months.
column2: Integrated Device Technology Inc. (IDTI) on Monday reported fiscal fourth-quarter net income of $20.7 million. Earnings, adjusted for one-time gains and costs, came to 46 cents per share. The results exceeded Wall Street expectations. For the year, the company reported a loss of $12.1 million,. Revenue was reported as $842.8 million.
column3: Lilly's offer of $50 per share in cash represents a premium of 68 percent to Armo's Wednesday close. Lilly already has a large portfolio of cancer treatments. Its lung cancer drug, Alimta, helped it comfortably beat analysts' profit expectations for the first quarter. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the second quarter of 2018. The deal gives Lilly access to the lead candidate, pegilodecakin, which is being studied in a late-stage
column4: Boeing booked 912 net orders in 2017, up from 903 in 2012. The company delivered 763 planes in 2012, down from 803 in 2011. It is the 15th year in a row that it has delivered more than it has cancellations. It has ordered more than 1,000 new planes in the last 10 years, more than any other manufacturer. The number of cancellations has fallen to the lowest level since 2001.
column5: Deutsche Bank plans to launch the initial public offering (IPO) of its asset management arm DWS. The listing of DWS on the Frankfurt stock exchange would likely take place in the week starting March 19. No new shares would be sold as part of the offering, sources said. The debut will take place before Holy Week, the week before the Easter holidays, as some investors are expected to be away.
column6: So far this month, the Brent has risen by 6.3 percent, making this its biggest rise in January since 2013. A key driver has been the dollar, which has lost 3.2 percent this year. U.S. energy firms added 12 drilling rigs for new production in the week to Jan. 26, taking the total to 759, Baker Hughes reported. The market is at risk from profit-taking, Julius Baer's head of macro and commodity research Norbert
column7: The $0.40 per share quarterly dividend for the second quarter of fiscal year 2018 will be payable on . The dividend was approved by shareholders at the company's annual general meeting held on . With 78,000 employees, including more than 7,000 engineers, working alongside customers in nearly 150 countries, TE ensures that EVERY CONNECTION COUNTS.
column8: Williams-Sonoma Inc. (WSM) on Wednesday reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $95.8 million. The results topped Wall Street expectations. The seller of cookware and home furnishings posted revenue of $1.68 billion in the period. For the year, the company reported profit of $259.5 million, or $3.02 per share, and revenue was reported as $5.29 billion.
column9: Ted Collins, Jr. joined the board of directors of Kimbell Royalty Partners at the time of KRP's initial public offering in early 2017. Mr. Collins' distinguished career in the oil and gas exploration and production business spanned more than five decades. "We are very sad to lose him both as a good friend and as a wise counselor," said Robert Ravnaas, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer.
column10: Ambien maker Sanofi says racism is not a known side effect of Ambien. Roseanne Barr said she was "ambien tweeting" when she compared Valerie Jarrett to an ape. The tweet has since been removed. ABC canceled her show "Roseanne" on Tuesday following the tweet. The actress apologized and asked her followers not to defend her, though she continued to retweet posts from fans who did.
column11: Consolidated Edison, Inc. plans to report its 2017 earnings on after the market closes. The company is one of the nation's largest investor-owned energy-delivery companies with approximately $12 billion in annual revenues and $49 billion in assets. It provides a wide range of energy-related products and services to its customers through the following subsidiaries: Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., a regulated utility providing electric, gas, and steam service in
column12: Japan has a perennial shortage of child care services. There aren't enough "baby care teachers" in the country at the moment. The job applicant ratio is skewed such that there are about six jobs available per candidate, an official says. It's not just a perk: It's essential for helping working mothers make an easier transition back into the workforce, he says. He says Pasona was the first organization in Japan, or a public company, to have a babysitting facility.
column13: Steve Wynn sold 4.1 million shares of Wynn Resorts at $180 per share, the filing showed. Now makes him the third-biggest shareholder in the company, behind his former wife Elaine Wynn and The Vanguard Group Inc. Steve Wynn resigned as CEO of the Las Vegas-based company last month, following claims he subjected women who worked for him to unwanted advances.
column14: The RNC is investigating allegations of sexual misconduct by members of its board. The allegations date back to the 1990s. The RNC says it is investigating the allegations in order to protect the reputation of its members. The board is expected to make a decision by the end of the month. The report will be made public once the investigation is complete. For more information on the RNC's investigation, go to:
column15: SkyWest, Inc. will host a conference call after the market closes on Thursday, , to discuss the first quarter 2018 results. The format will provide an overview of the results followed by a Q&A session. US callers can access the call live via PR Newswire Webcast at: A digital rebroadcast of the conference call will be available
column16: Mercantile Bank Corporation will hold a conference call to discuss first quarter 2018 results on Tuesday, , at 10:00 a.m. Eastern Time. Interested parties may access the conference call by dialing 1-844-868-8844; passcode 10118375. The conference call will also be webcast live at ir.mercbank.com . An audio archive will be available on the Mercantile website following the call.
column17: Matthew Schwall was director of field performance engineering at Tesla. He left at a time when the National Transportation Safety Board has been investigating multiple crashes involving the electric vehicles. Schwall joined Waymo's safety team led by former National Highway Traffic Safety Administration Deputy Administrator Ron Medford. The former Tesla executive began at Waymo last Monday and will work on a variety of self-driving car safety issues in his new role.
column18: TriplePoint Venture Growth BDC Corp. reported fourth-quarter net income of $3.9 million. The investment company posted revenue of $11.1 million in the period. For the year, the company reported profit of $19.2 million, or $1.18 per share. The company's shares have fallen 7 percent since the beginning of the year.. In the final minutes of trading on Monday, shares hit $ 11.80, a fall of 10 percent
column19: Kellie Ell is a News Associate for CNBC. She attended the CNBC Business News Associate Workshop at #AAJA18 in Houston. Ell: "The workshop showed me how CNBC is the first in breaking news and uncovering stories. Coming from a print background, nothing moves as fast as CNBC." The workshop also showed me that CNBC values diversity. You don't have to have a background in business journalism to apply for the workshop or to be part of CNBC.
column20: Kratos Defense & Security Solutions Inc. (KTOS) lost $2.2 million in its first quarter. On a per-share basis, the San Diego-based company said it had a loss of 2 cents. For the current quarter ending in July, Kratos said it expects revenue in the range of $140 million to $150 million. The company expects full-year revenue of $640 million and $650 million.

Altice N.V. will release its Q4 2017 results separately on Thursday, . Dial-in access telephone numbers and webcast details will be made available a week ahead of the conference call.
column23: Stanley Black & Decker's Board of Directors approved a regular second quarter cash dividend of $0.63 per common share. This extends the company's record for the longest consecutive annual and quarterly dividend payments among industrial companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange. The dividend is payable on Tuesday, to shareholders of record as of the close of business on Wednesday, .
column24: The president pledges federal help to the Florida community reeling from the murders. A former student opened fire with a semiautomatic rifle at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School. The 19-year-old suspect, Nikolas Cruz, was charged with 17 counts of premeditated murder. The shooting is the latest in a string of killings at schools in the United States in recent years.
column25: "Asia has the highest number of first- and second-generation entrepreneurs, which drives the economy," Credit Suisse Asia Pacific CEO Helman Sitohang tells CNBC. He said he expects a "robust" performance from regional capital markets this year amid expectations for the Federal Reserve to embark on four hike interest rate hikes. The focus was particularly on entrepreneurs with large- and mid-sized endeavors.
column26: The Company plans to hold a live webcast on Tuesday, , at 11:00AM Eastern Time, to discuss its results for the first quarter ended . You may listen to the webcast by accessing the event link on the Company's investor website at . The Company will release its quarterly results on after the closing of regular trading on the NASDAQ Stock Market.
column27: Amazon.com is bringing its grocery store without checkout lines to Chicago and San Francisco. Customers scan a smartphone app to enter the store, and then cameras and sensors track what they remove from the shelves and what they put back. Amazon then bills shoppers' credit cards on file after they leave. It was not clear when the new stores will open. The concept has the potential to alter brick-and-mortar retail.
column28: Quaker Chemical Corporation (NYSE: KWR) announces fourth quarter and full year earnings release and investor conference. Earnings Release: (after market close) Teleconference: , 8:30 a.m. (ET) Webcast: . Quaker Chemical is a leading global provider of process fluids, chemical specialties, and technical expertise.
column29: Teligent, Inc. initially announced the Company would hold a conference call at 4:30pm ET on Monday, to discuss the 1 st quarter 2018 financial results and business update. This call will be rescheduled for 8:30am ET on Tuesday, . The Company invites you to listen to the call by dialing (866) 393-8366.
column30: Paylocity Holding Corporation (Nasdaq:PCTY) announces its conference call to review its second quarter fiscal 2018 results. The conference call is scheduled for Thursday, Feb. 8, 2018 at 4 p.m. Central Time (5 p.M. Eastern Time). To listen to the conference call live, dial (855) 226-3021 or (315) 625-6892.
column31: Alphabet Inc's Google said on Tuesday it would add five regions and build three new submarine cables. The company, which has invested $30 billion in infrastructure over the past three years, said its Netherlands and Montreal regions will open in the first quarter of 2018. Google plans to commission the three subsea cables in 2019. Subsea cables form the backbone of the internet by carrying more than 90 percent of the world's data traffic.
column32: QAD Inc. (QADA) reported fiscal first-quarter net income of $1.4 million. The company expects full-year revenue in the range of $328 million to $332 million. QAD shares have risen 21 percent since the beginning of the year. In the final minutes of trading on Wednesday, shares hit $47.20, a climb of 46 percent in the last 12 months.
column33: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is expected to address the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee. He is anticipated to offer his testimony on interest rates, the debt ceiling, and the economy. At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, the U.S. dollar took a significant dent after Mnuchin told reporters "a weaker dollar is good for us as it relates to trade and opportunities"
column34: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is expected to provide new details about a tool designed to help Americans calculate adjustments to their tax withholding. The calculator, which was announced in January, is supposed to help taxpayers update their withholding forms in accordance with the newly implemented tax law. The withholding calculator is being released by the Internal Revenue Service. The stream is slated to start at 2:45 p.m., ET.
column35: Nintendo estimated profit to reach 225 billion yen ($2.06 billion) from 177.56 billion yen a year prior. If achieved, it would be Nintendo's highest operating profit since the year ended March 2010. The outlook compared with the 308.72 billion yen average of 21 analyst estimates in a survey by Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.Kyoto-based Nintendo is aiming to sell 20 million Switch consoles in the financial year started April.
column36: 23-month-old Alfie Evans had an incurable degenerative brain condition. His parents fought for months to take him to a hospital in Italy so he could be kept on life support. U.K. authorities denied his parents' attempts to transport him abroad to receive experimental treatment. Evans had a degenerative condition, and doctors pulled his life support earlier this week. The case drew attention from Pope Francis and others around the world.
column37: Deutsche Bank chairman to hold call with board over CEO: Handelsblatt. Achleitner has invited the supervisory board to an "Update Call", the paper reported. The British chief executive officer has been in office less than three years. The bank reported a third consecutive annual loss last year. The annual general meeting for Deutsche Bank is scheduled for May 24. The German bank declined to comment on the report.
column38: Kansas City Life Insurance Company recorded net income of $1.5 million or $0.15 per share in the first quarter of 2018. The Company's primary business is providing financial protection through the sale of life insurance and annuities. The company was established in 1895 and is based in Kansas City, Missouri. For more information, please visit
column39: Lake Worth spokesman Ben Kerr says an independent investigation is underway to determine who was behind the message. Kerr says officials determined that no current or former employees edited the pre-prepared message to include the warning of a zombie invasion. He tells the Palm Beach Post that "no one was fired for it" He said a hacking issue came up during Hurricane Irma last September. But that issue was dealt with quickly.
column40: KB Home (KBH) on Thursday reported a fiscal first-quarter loss of $71.3 million. The Los Angeles-based company said it had a loss of 82 cents per share. Earnings, adjusted for non-recurring costs, were 40 cents per quarter. KB Home shares have declined almost 10 percent since the beginning of the year.. In the final minutes of trading on Thursday, shares hit $28.84.
column41: Financial 15 Split Corp. declares its regular monthly distribution of $0.12570 for each Class A share ($1.51 annually) and $ 0.04583 for each Preferred share ($0.550 annually) Distributions are payable to shareholders on record as at . Financial 15 invests in a high quality portfolio consisting of 15 financial services companies made up of Canadian and U.S. issuers.
column42: Kevin Kennedy, president of a steel fabrication business in Texas, says tariffs on steel and aluminum imports have led U.S. steel producers to raise their prices by 40 percent. He says that's shifting work to competitors outside the U.s. Kennedy is appearing before the House Ways and Means Committee, which is examining the impact of tariffs. Lawmakers later Thursday are scheduled to meet with President Donald Trump to talk about trade.
column43: The Tesla Model 3 is an enjoyable car to drive, but some features disappoint, Consumer Reports says. The car's "glued-to-the-road handling" impressed testers, the publication says. But testers criticized certain features, such as an "overly stiff ride" and door handles that are "unnatural and awkward" The publication will continue to test the car in the coming weeks and will provide a full review and rating.
column44: Facebook has begun putting together a team of people who can work on chip designs. The company wants a manager who can "build and manage an end-to-end SoC/ASIC, firmware and driver development organization" Chipmaker Intel's stock dropped slightly right after the news came out, then quickly rebounded. Facebook has shown interest in trying Intel's special-purpose chips for AI.
column45: Cathay General Bancorp (CATY) on Tuesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $25.9 million. The results did not meet Wall Street expectations. For the year, the company reported profit of $176 million, or $2.17 per share.Cathay shares have risen 3 percent since the beginning of the year. In the final minutes of trading on Tuesday, shares hit $43.53.
column46: UK High Court grants Cambridge Analytica search warrant to ICO. A British High Court judge has granted an application by the Information Commissioner's office for a warrant to search the company's London offices. ICO sought a warrant after a whistleblower revealed it had harvested the private information of millions of Facebook users to support Donald Trump 's 2016 U.S. presidential campaign. "We are pleased with the decision of the judge, and we plan to execute the warrant shortly," an ICO spokesman said.
column47: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's decision not to answer questions from British lawmakers is "astonishing", says Damian Collins. Collins, Chair of the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport select committee, was speaking during a hearing with a whistleblower. "It is absolutely astonishing that Mark Zuckerberg is not prepared to submit himself to questioning," he said. Collins added: "We would certainly urge him to think again if he has any care for people that use his company's services"
column48: Chesapeake Utilities Corporation will host a conference call on Friday, , at 10:30 a.m. ET to discuss the Company's financial results and year ended . The earnings press release will be issued on Wednesday, . To participate in this call, dial 855.801.6270 and reference Chesapeake Utilities Corp's 2017 Financial Results Conference Call.
column49: You are invited to participate on a conference call with the senior management of Arcos Dorados (NYSE: ARCO) to discuss the Company's results for the fourth quarter and full year ended . Sergio Alonso, Chief Executive Officer, and senior management will host the call. Remarks will be followed by a question and answer period. Callers who pre-register will be given a unique PIN to gain immediate access to the call and bypass the live operator.
column50: Bank of America Merrill Lynch chief investment strategist Michael Hartnett has been calling for a correction. He said the market should find a floor quickly, but that it will have to retest that floor. The 200-day moving average, seen as the next technical zone to be tested, is 2,538 on the S&P.Hartnett said there are a series of events that need to occur before the market sell off is over.
column51: Foot Locker shares rallied more than 16 after the company reported adjusted earnings per share at $1.45 for the first quarter. The shoe store posted revenue of $2.03 billion, which also beat forecasts. Fears that e-commerce giant Amazon may seek to expand into apparel have made it a tough year for Foot Locker Shares, now down more than 22 percent over the past 12 months.
column52: Sabra Health Care REIT, Inc. will issue its 2017 fourth quarter earnings release on . A conference call with a simultaneous webcast will be held on Thursday, February 22 at 10:00 a.m. Pacific Time. A digital replay of the call will be available on our website at . Also, on , Sabra's board of directors declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.45 per
column53: Codexis Inc. (CDXS) on Thursday reported a loss of $4.7 million in its first quarter. The producer of custom industrial enzymes posted revenue of $14 million in the period. Codexis expects full-year revenue in the range of $60 million to $63 million. The company's shares have climbed 40 percent since the beginning of the year, more than doubling in the last 12 months.
column54: BAE Systems is the most high-profile firm to be pulled from the fund's collective investment. Norges Bank, which administrates the fund on behalf of the Norwegian government, said it had also decided to exclude U.S. engineering firms AECOM and Fluor, as well as shipbuilder Huntington Ingalls Industries. For all of those firms, involvement in the production of nuclear weapons was the reason given for the bans.
column55: The North did not give a reason for the cancellation, the Unification Ministry said. A seven-member team had been scheduled to visit on Saturday to check venues for the performances. It was unclear whether the cancellation cast any doubt over the North's participation in the Winter Olympics in South Korea's Pyeongchang. North Korean Olympic officials arrived in Switzerland on Thursday ahead of weekend talks at the International Olympic Committee (IOC)
column56: Researchers at MIT have designed a fleet of 3D-printed autonomous boats. The driverless boats could eventually taxi people and deliver goods. The goal is to eventually program the boats to self-assemble into larger structures, like floating docks and concert stages. MIT says they can also be equipped to monitor a city's water quality. In 2016, a prototype was tested within Amsterdam's canal system to provide research on how urban waterways can be used more efficiently.
column57: Inventor Peter Madsen sentenced to life in prison for murdering and dismembering a Swedish journalist. Madsen, 47, sat completely still as his sentence was handed down in the Copenhagen City Court. Police detained him on August 11 last year when he emerged from his submarine without Wall, 30, who had boarded the vessel the previous day to do research on a story about Madsen. Police identified a torso washed ashore in Copenhagen as Wall's.
column58: Pangolin Diamonds Corp. (TSX-V:PAN) announces the resignation of Mr. Gareth Penny as Chairman of the Company, effective , due to other time commitments. Mr. Penny will remain as an advisor to the Board. For more information on Pangolin, please visit our website at
column59: Zscaler dropped $2.87, or 9.6 percent, to $27.08 as of mid-day on Thursday. The company went public in March and has a stock market value of over $3 billion. CEO Jay Chaudhry thanked William Welch for his contributions but didn't say why he was leaving or whether there was a replacement lined up. Zscaler provides security to companies operating in cloud environments like Amazon Web Services and Microsoft Azure.
column60: The Board of Directors of S&T Bancorp, Inc. (S&T) (NASDAQ: STBA) declared a $0.22 per share cash dividend at its regular meeting held . column61: The Alhambra, California-based company said it had a loss of less than 1 cent on a per-share basis. Earnings, adjusted for one-time gains and costs, were 3 cents per share. For the current quarter ending in April, Emcore said it expects revenue in the range of $21 million to $23 million. The stock has fallen 32 percent in the last 12 months.
column62: Rockwell Collins will issue a press release reporting its second quarter fiscal year 2018 financial results at approximately 6:30 a.m. Eastern Time on Friday, . In light of the announced transaction with United Technologies Corp. (UTX), the company will not hold a conference call for its results for the second quarter. Rockwell Collins is a leader in aviation and high-integrity solutions for commercial and military customers around the world.
column63: Rosenstein made the revelation in a court filing on Monday. None of the charges against him alleges co-ordination with the Kremlin. But they do allege that he colluded with Russian officials to influence the election. The White House has said it will not comment on the allegations until the case is heard by a grand jury next month. The case is expected to be heard by the end of the month.
column64: Brazilian prosecutors ask BNY Mellon unit to return $2.5 bln to local fund. BNY has failed to monitor the risks Postalis was subject to as a result of investments, prosecutors say. A Sao Paulo court now will decide if the bank will face charges.BNY Mellon did not immediately respond to requests for comment. Ã¢â‚¬â„¢â‚¬â€™ â€œâ€�ï¿½
column65: Dutch speciality chemicals group DSM pre-announced better-than-expected earnings for the first quarter. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization rose to 535 million euros ($661.3 million) from 345 million a year earlier. DSM raised its 2018 adjusted EBITDA forecast to "toward" 25 percent from earlier guidance for a rise of at least high single-digit growth.
column66: Nordstrom stock fell nearly 3 percent after hours. Members of the Nordstrom family proposed an offer to take the company private. The family still hopes to successfully take Nordstrom private this year. Ascena Retail Group plunged more than 12 percent in extended trading. Same-store sales were down 2 percent this quarter and guidance for the upcoming quarter was weak. Analogic shares rose nearly 8 percent before settling after the bell.

column68: Shares of Five Below gained 1 percent in the extended session. Herman Miller stock dropped close to 3 percent after the bell after the home furnishings manufacturer reported third quarter financial results. Altair Engineering fell 1.5 percent after issuing first quarter guidance that disappointed analysts. Facebook stock edged up in extended trading following reports of a scandal with firm Cambridge Analytica, CEO Mark Zuckerberg and COO Sheryl Sandberg released statements.

column72: Barclays has spoken to its rival bank Standard Chartered about a potential merger. No formal or informal bid was made, the Financial Times reported on Wednesday. Barclays had no comment when contacted by CNBC. Stanchart said it's "entirely focused on executing our strategy, and [does] not comment on this type of speculation" The conversation that took place was part of a wider effort by Barclays to improve its financial performance.
column73: Central Pacific Financial Corp. will release its first quarter 2018 earnings on , before the open of the New York Stock Exchange. Management will review the results by conference call and live audio webcast beginning at 1:00 p.m. Eastern Time. The conference call can be accessed by calling 1-877-505-7644 or by listening to the webcast on the company's investor relations website at
column74: The Internet Association says it intends to join an expected lawsuit against a decision to roll back net neutrality rules. Several states including New York, and public interest advocacy groups have said they intend to sue to stop the ruling. The approval of FCC Chairman Ajit Pai's proposal in a 3-2 vote marked a victory for internet service providers such as AT&T Inc, Comcast Corp and Verizon Communications Inc.
column75: Former FBI director James Comey will visit Amazon on Monday for a fireside chat. Comey is participating in one of Amazon's "Fishbowl" events on the company's campus. He will discuss his new book "A Higher Loyalty: Truth Lies and Leadership," which was released earlier this week. Amazon has hosted other politicians, including John Kasich, on its campus. 35 authors spoke at its Fishbowl gatherings in the last year.
column76: Fortinet Inc. (FTNT) on Thursday reported first-quarter profit of $41.6 million. On a per-share basis, the Sunnyvale, California-based company said it had profit of 24 cents. Earnings, adjusted for one-time gains and costs, came to 33 cents per share. For the current quarter ending in July, Fortinet expects earnings to range from 34 cents to 36 cents.
column77: SandRidge says it has received interest regarding "alternative transactions" from other producers. Oklahoma-based Midstates Petroleum, backed by activist shareholder Fir Tree Partners, had offered to buy SandRidge last month. The offer was made after activist shareholder Carl Icahn scuppered SandR Ridge's plans to buy Bonanza Creek Energy. Under Midstates offer, SandRidges shareholders were to hold 60 percent of the combined company.
column78: Hexcel Corporation will report results for its fiscal 2017 fourth quarter on Wednesday, after the market close. The company will host a webcast and conference call to discuss highlights of its financial results on Thursday, January 25, at 10 a.m. ET. The call will be hosted by Chairman, CEO and President Nick Stanage and Chief Financial Officer Patrick Winterlich.
column79: President Donald Trump will undergo a routine physical on Friday. Trump is getting the customary health check amid questions about his fitness for office. A summary of the results is typically made public, at least it has been during prior administrations. But already his diet has been widely discussed, including his proclivity for fast food, well-done steak with ketchup and diet cola. "It better go well otherwise the stock market will not be happy," Trump said.
column80: Starbucks will close 8,000 company-owned U.S. cafes for the afternoon on May 29. Announcement comes as it tries to cool tensions after the arrest of two black men at one of its cafes last week. Chief Executive Kevin Johnson: "We're committed to being a part of the solution" Starbucks shares were up 0.6 percent at $59.81 in afternoon trading.
column81: Great Elm Capital Corp. will host a conference call and webcast on Monday, at 9:00 a.m. New York City time to discuss its fourth quarter financial results. All interested parties are invited to participate in the conference call by dialing +1 (844) 820-8297. The conference call will be webcast simultaneously at: .
column82: array BioPharma Inc. will report financial results for the second quarter of fiscal 2018 and hold a conference call to discuss those results on Tuesday, . Ron Squarer, Chief Executive Officer, will lead the call. The conference call will be held at 9:00 a.m. Eastern Time. The webcast will be available on the company's website and on the conference call.
column83: Japan is the only major U.S. ally that did not receive exemptions from President Donald Trump's decision. It had previously refrained from following in the footsteps of China and the European Union, which responded with reciprocal threats. Tariffs Japan will shoulder under the new duties come to about 50 billion yen ($450 million) a year. The ministry said Japan had notified the WTO it reserved the right to take rebalancing measures worth that amount.

column85: Sandvik's welding wire business generated revenues of approximately 500 million SEK in the twelve months to September 30th, 2017. The deal includes the production units in Sandviken, Sweden and Scranton, US as well as the global sales and product management organization; in total approximately 100 employees. The divestment will have a positive cash flow impact of about 260 millionSEK upon closing.
column86: Callaway Golf Co. (ELY) reported a fourth-quarter loss of $19.4 million. The Carlsbad, California-based company said it had a loss of 20 cents. For the year, the company reported profit of $40.8 million, or 42 cents per share. The company expects full-year earnings to be 64 cents to 70 cents per cent, with revenue ranging from $1.12 billion to $1 million.
column87: The charge against the governor apparently stems from a 2015 affair. Greitens, 43, allegedly threatened to release a nude photograph of a woman, blindfolded and hands bound, if she talked publicly about the relationship. He acknowledged the relationship but told the Associated Press that he did not try to coerce the woman. "This was a consensual relationship," he told the AP last month.
column88: TimkenSteel Corp. will release its 2018 first-quarter financial results on Thursday, April 26, after the market closes on the New York Stock Exchange. The company will host a conference call at 9 a.m. ET on Friday, April 27, to discuss its financial performance with investors and securities analysts. The financial results and conference call materials will be available online at investors.timkensteel.com.
column89: Nordstrom is in the midst of its effort take the company private. The company has been looking to round up financing for those efforts. Nordstrom is among a list of retailers, including Macy's , J.C. Penney and Kohl's which reported strong sales this holiday season. Investors will be looking to see how those holiday sales impacted its fourth quarter performance.. Of most importance for financing sources is Nordstrom's ability to demonstrate stability and continued e-commerce momentum.
column90: WPP's board appointed an independent counsel to investigate Sir Martin Sorrell. The ongoing investigation doesn't appear to be material to the business, the company said. Sorrell is considered a captain of industry and savvy dealmaker. He was knighted in 2000 after growing WPP from a small company, Wire and Plastics Products, to a dominant ad company with over 200,000 employees.
column91: TrueCar Inc. (TRUE) on Tuesday reported a loss of $9.1 million in its first quarter. The results missed Wall Street expectations. The provider of localized information on new car costs posted revenue of $81.1million. For the current quarter ending in July, TrueCar said it expects revenue in the range of $87 million to $89 million. The company expects full-year revenue to be between $360 million and $365 million.
column92: OncoMed Pharmaceuticals Inc. (OMED) reported fourth-quarter net income of $9.5 million. The results beat Wall Street expectations. The cancer therapy developer posted revenue of $20.6 million in the period. For the year, the company reported that its loss narrowed to $39.1 million, or $1.04 per share. The company's shares hit $2.89 in final minutes of trading.
column93: Former White House chief strategist Steve Bannon has proposed a plan to end the investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia. He said the White House should stop cooperating with special counsel Robert Mueller and fire him. The plan would create "a new legal battleground" for Trump to "protect himself from the investigation," according to the Washington Post. Some of Trump's advisors fear the plan could lead to mass resignations at the Justice Department.
column94: HP Inc. (HPQ) on Tuesday reported fiscal second-quarter profit of $1.06 billion. The Palo Alto, California-based company said it had net income of 64 cents per share. For the current quarter ending in August, HP expects its per-share earnings to range from 49 cents to 52 cents.HP shares have risen roughly 2 percent since the beginning of the year.
column95: PS Business Parks Inc. (PSB) on Tuesday reported a key measure of profitability in its first quarter. The Glendale, California-based real estate investment trust said it had funds from operations of $55.6 million. The company's shares have decreased roughly 8 percent since the beginning of the year. In the final minutes of trading on Tuesday, shares hit $115.45, a decline of roughly 5 percent.
column96: LendingClub Corp. (LC) on Tuesday reported a loss of $92 million in its fourth quarter. The results did not meet Wall Street expectations. The company that connects borrowers and lenders online posted revenue of $156.5 million in the period. For the current quarter ending in April, LendingClub said it expects revenue in the range of $145 million to $155 million.
column97: Louisiana-Pacific Corporation (LP) (NYSE:LPX) announced today that its board of directors has approved a $0.13 per share dividend. The dividend will be paid on to shareholders of record at the close of business on . Founded in 1973, LP is a global company headquartered in Nashville, Tennessee, and traded on the New York Stock exchange under LPX.
column98: Rollins, Inc. is a premier global consumer and commercial services company. The Board of Directors declared a regular quarterly cash dividend on its common stock of $0.14 per share payable to stockholders of record at the close of business . The Company provides essential pest control services and protection against termite damage, rodents and insects to more than two million customers in the United States, Canada, Central America, South America, the Caribbean, the Middle
column99: "We conclude that a US recession is unlikely until Q3 2020," analyst says. "Remain overweight equities," he adds. High volatility is also here to stay, meaning credit is more risky than equity, Garthwaite says. But the Credit Suisse analyst is not bullish on all sectors, calling them "expensive and "over-owned" "At this stage of yield curve flattening, software and energy are the best performing sectors," he says.
column100: The oceanic whitetip shark will be listed as "threatened" under the Endangered Species Act. The shark lives along the East Coast of the United States, off southern California and in international waters all over the world. Conservation group Defenders of Wildlife called on the government to list the species.Scientists say the sharks have declined by 80 to 90 percent in the Pacific Ocean since the 1990s.
